ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I took this class to learn from Bill and Amy, but they did a total of maybe 4 lectures. The rest of the class was student led, or led by a guest lecturer. I did not come to Yale to learn how to teach classes. I came to learn from professors, not students who don't have a firm grasp of the material yet.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The open, thorough discussions
The boot camp videos were extremely helpful and could have even been taught in person for greater benefit. I also enjoyed the speakers each week.

I appreciated the species/wildlife focus on conservation given that it is different than other conservation courses offered at FES. I enjoyed the professor led components of the course most, and really appreciated the last class about careers and juggling family and work. In general the speakers were great, and it was nice to have an opportunity to connect with them over dinner. Amy and Billy do a great job selecting a wide range of speakers (topically, geographically, discipline, professional role, etc). That said, some weeks it was pretty rough to have the speakers present on Thursday evening (the end of the week for most of us)...I wish these could have been at another time. I also thought the "conservation bootcamp" at the beginning (mainly the science component, which I am less familiar with) was great. I would suggest expanding this.
Learning from Amy and Bill and hearing about their story and experience.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: There needs to be more of a diversity of class types. Every single class was either student led or led by a guest lecturer. Especially for students who do not feel comfortable speaking out a lot in class, this wasn't conducive to much learning. Class discussions got out of hand, making it even harder for quiet people to participate or even want to participate.
The student led discussions are too much of the course and not as educational as they should be. Also, we could benefit from time to discussion the guest speaker's lectures in class.

Student-led classes were definitely not ideal for learning the material. Each group seemed to pick topics and readings they liked or had experience with but this led to a lot of discontinuity between sessions. It would be helpful if student-led classes were more focused or if the entire semester worked on just one or two case studies.

The student led courses were pretty rough, with a few exceptions. I know that Amy and Bill feel strongly that this is an important skill for students to have, and while I understand the argument I also think I am paying way too much money to be at FES to be taught that much by other students. I would recommend that this component be significantly downsized. Maybe it was because the student-led courses didn't clearly convey the different topic areas they were supposed to relate to, but I also struggled to see a structural arc to the class. I felt like we were having the same conversations in week 2 and 3 as at the end of the semester, and that got repetitive. I think it needs to be clearer what is being covered each week, and for there to be key learnings in all of the areas covered (instead of just loose conversation). Lastly, I think it's a missed opportunity not to take time to discuss the speakers in class. We heard some really interesting and compelling people speak, and then never had the opportunity to process their presentations with our peers. I think time should be devoted to this during subsequent classes, and maybe students should also have to respond to speakers during discussion posts. Brad Gentry's "Strategies for Land Conservation" class is a fantastic example of how to incorporate readings, speakers, and student-led discussions. In general I think Amy and Bill are trying to fit too many things into this class, and that leads to a lack of coherence. I think if the student-led portion was downsized it would free up time for the professors' key takeaways and post-speaker discussions, and help bring together everything else into a more coherent semester-long experience.

The course was basically either students presenting on topics they don't know much about or guest speakers. There should be more courses when Amy and Bill teach us about conservation. I think that if student presentations only took half the class and then Amy and Bill actually taught us about the topic for the other half of the class, we could learn a lot more. I did not get that much from the student presentations because it did not feel like my classmates knew enough about the topic.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: from SOM was great
This class fits perfectly into my program since I am focusing on wildlife conservation issues. I would highly recommend it for anyone with a conservation focus.

I'm focusing on conservation, and this class provided an opportunity to think more about the international scale. It also acquainted me with some important case studies. Although I didn't realize it going in, I also learned a lot about wildlife conservation (I would emphasize this more in the class description).

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: exposure to FES, Interested in content
I wanted to learn from Amy and Bill
I wanted to scale up my conservation understanding.

I took this class because of my focus in wildlife conservation but also because of Amy and Bill. They have so much knowledge and experience in the field of wildlife conservation that they are amazing resources.
To get insight into international work going on in the space, and to learn more about being a professional (opposed to academic) in this field.
I am interested in conservation and wanted to take this course with professors that have real world experience

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: more ethan
I would have liked spending more time at the beginning of the semester on the topics covered in the bootcamp. Some of that information was very practical and foundational to conservation work.

This course fell short of my expectations for the reasons above, but was still useful. Amy and Bill are really interesting and willing to share all about their work. I benefited from hearing about their professional experiences, and from the deep content-dives we did with the speakers. I also benefited from the species focus.
Partly, I don't feel like I learned as much as I would have if the profs taught more of the course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: shared opinions
I had no objections to working with a group, although as I said I thought this student-led section of the course was overly weighted.
Great for mini break out discussions before larger class codscusskons

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: definately take it
Make sure you say something every class because this is how you participate. Even if what you say is bullshit, it's the only way your participation is measured.
Take advantage of the chance to get to know Amy and Bill. They are great resources if you're going into conservation and super willing to help out at any point.

Amy and Bill are amazing and it is worth taking a course with them. However, this course felt a bit like a lot of uninformed discussion. We kept arguing based on our own knowledge of things but we didn't do too much learning since it was all student-led lectures that did not cover anything very deeply. Maybe their other course is more applied.
